AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: best known for its thick, corky bark and massive branches
opposite, pinnately compound, made up of 7-13 dark green leaflets
thick, somewhat spongy and deeply furrowed on mature trees
yellowish-green, inconspicuous either male or female flowers
male trees do not produce fruit; female trees produce berry-like clusters

The Amur Corktree is native to Northern China and was introduced to the U.S. around 1856. In 1906 the Arnold Arboretum acquired the Amur Corktree and subsequently the general public became aware of this tree. The well-defined, thick, corky bark is reflected in the botanical name for the Amur Corktree, ‘Phellodendron amurense.’ This name can be translated from the Greek words, phellos, meaning cork and, dendrum, meaning bark. In addition, amurense, refers to the Amur region of Asia, the tree’s place of origin. The corky bark has a distinctive yellow inner bark that is easy to spot. The aptly named tree has massive branches that spread as wide as its height. The winding branches and the textured, corky bark give the Amur Corktree added winter interest. This tree rarely has disease or insect problem and can tolerate drought and alkaline conditions. Because the Amur Corktree can grow to be a large tree, it has been planted often on college campuses and in parks where space is not a concern. The tree’s wide spreading root system and large canopy limit its use near streets. The bright yellow inner bark of the Amur Corktree was used to produce a yellow dye in Ancient China. The bark is also used in traditional Chinese medicine. It is said to be one of the 50 fundamental herbs used medicinally. In recent years, the pharmaceutical industry has shown interest in the Amur Corktree bark because of the phyto chemicals it possesses. Research is just beginning to explore this frontier. Amur Corktree fruit oil also has some unique qualities. The oil has insecticidal benefits similar to pyrethrum, a popular natural insecticide. Because the Amur Corktree grows quickly and easily, it has become nearly invasive in some parts of New England. When the seed escapes into forest areas, it tends to dominate native species. Consequently, the planting of the Amur Corktree near forests is not recommended. While walking on the east side of WSU’s Science Laboratory Center and Stark Hall, notice the perimeter planting of a dozen or more 20-year-old Amur Corktrees.
